question.prompt: What would you say is your biggest challenge with diet?
question.option: I eat when I am stressed
I am hungry all the time
I eat when I am bored

question.prompt: Do you track what you eat?
Do you often feel tired, fatigued, or sleepy during daytime?
What is the major source of your stress?
Where do you do the majority of your stress eating?
Where do you experience the most temptations or the greatest willpower challenges?
How many days a week do you skip one or more meals?
Where do you experience the most hunger?
Where do you eat when you are bored?
Which one would best describe your lifestyle?
question.option: I have a job which has a lot of downtime
I am busy during the day, but I'm home in the evening

question.prompt: On average, how many days a week do you cook dinner at home?
How many meals a week do you eat in restaurant or carry-out?
How many times do you eat out between Friday night and Sunday night?
How many servings of alcohol do you have between Friday night and Sunday night?
In a given month, how many weekends do you have or attend parties?
Do you have larger meals at home on the weekends?
Which of these are your challenges at parties?
question.option: Feel pressure from others to eat
A large variety of food to try

question.prompt: Which of the following sugary beverages do you drink?
Which of the following alchoholic beverages do you drink the most?
Do you feel like you make unhealthy food choices when you drink?

solutions.solution: Add a meal where you are used to skipping to prevent hunger.
Add extra exercise the day of a party to offset added intake. Record it all in your mobile app.
Add some yoga to your week to reduce stress.
Adjust recipes so that you only make one serving per person
Allow yourself one plate. Serve small portions.
Ask a friend or family member at the party to help you control your intake.
Ask coworkers to bring in healthy snacks to share rather than unhealthy treats.
Ask for drinks on the rocks so it slowly dilutes.
Ask for recipes instead of leftovers so you don't feel like you are missing out.
Ask someone in the house to help you avoid tempting foods.
Ask someone to join you for grocery shopping to help you avoid buying tempting foods.
Ask someone with good willpower to do some of the grocery shopping so it doesn't always fall on you.
Ask the bartender to make your cocktail "skinny"
Ask the server to not bring bread to the table.
Ask the server to split the portion and box the second half before bringing it to table.
Ask your supervisor for additonal tasks during downtimes.
Avoid drinking on an empty stomach at parties. Drink after you've eaten.
Avoid impulse snacking on the weekend by planning snacks ahead of time.
Avoid sitting next to snack dishes at parties while drinking.
Before a party, ask your partner or a friend attending the party to help you deal with family members or friends that cause you stress.
Bring a healthy dish or snack to parties so you have at least one healthy option.
Bring a healthy lunch to work if cafeteria or restaurants lead you to make unhealthy choices.
Bring a healthy snack in the car for the commute/long rides.
Bring a healthy snack to eat on your commute home to prevent stress eating at home.
Bring a healthy snack to eat on your commute home to prevent stress eating.
Bring a healthy snack to eat on your commute to prevent stress eating.
Bring a lunch to work or school to avoid making food decisions while under stress.
Bring a lunch with you to avoid making food decisions while under stress.
Bring a veggie or fruit tray to all parties so you have something to overeat guilt-free.
Bring fresh fruit and yogurt dip to pass as a low calorie dessert
Bring healthy snacks to school so you have them on hand when hungry.
Bring healthy snacks to work so you have them on hand when hungry.
Bring healthy snacks with you to avoid stress eating junk food.
Bring healthy snacks with you to school each day.
Bring someone grocery shopping with you to help you keep to your list.
Buy non-fat milk versions
Calculate the number of times you eat out each week and eliminate at least one.
Call a friend on your commute when stressed to help calm down.
Change your route if you pass many tempting restaurants on your usual route.
Choose low calorie alcoholic drinks (e.g., light beer)
Choose low calorie alcoholic drinks (e.g., light beer, hard liquor and soda)
Come up with a way to reward yourself for every trip in which you stuck to a healthy list.
Confide in a friend when stressed instead of reaching for food.
Confide in a good friend when stressed instead of reaching for food.
Consider volunteer work.
Decide which food is your favorite and enjoy a full portion of that.
Delegate tasks at work to reduce your load and the stress that comes with it.
Dilute juice 1 part water to 3 parts lemonade. Gradually increase parts water over a few weeks.
Dilute juice with 1 part water to 3 parts juice. Gradually increase parts water over a few weeks.
Dilute premade versions with skim milk.
Dilute with club soda and ice.
Dilute with club soda.
Dilute with water.
Do diet tracking on weekend days to help reduce your intake.
Drink a coffee, tea, water or other low cal beverage during class instead of snacking.
Drink a glass of water in between alcoholic drinks to limit intake.
Drink a glass of water in between alcoholic drinks to slow you down and fill you up.
Drink a glass of water in between each drink to slow you down and fill you up.
Drink non-caloric flavored seltzers instead.
Eat prior to parties so you have less appetite at the party.
Email host in advance to let them know you are trying hard not to overeat.
Engage in an activity that distracts you from hunger to see if feeling passes.
Exercise after school to reduce stress from the day.
Exercise after work to reduce stress from the workday.
Fill up on raw veggies or salad before dinner so your appetite is more under control.
Find healthier versions of recipes for weekend family dinners
Find healthier versions of recipes for your favorite weekend breakfast foods
Find healthy recipes on the internet and compile a schedule of meals for the month.
Find quick healthy dinner ideas and plan to eat at home more often.
Freeze party leftovers and use for a meal later in the week.
Give yourself a limit for how many drinks you can have on one occasion/night and this will force you to spread them out.
Give yourself a limit for how many drinks you consume each week and keep track.
Go for a short walk to suppress appetite.
When willpower feels weak, go for a short walk to let the craving pass.
Go to the grocery store directly after a meal.
Go to the library to read or work on the computer.
Gradually reduce the amount of sugar added by 1/2 packet every 2 weeks.
Grocery shop on the weekend so you have ingredients for meals all week
Have fresh fruit washed and ready to eat at home at all times.
Have fresh fruit washed and ready to eat at work at all times.
Have healthy low calorie snacks available at work.
Have healthy low calorie snacks available in the home.
Have low calorie snacks (e.g., cut up veggies or fruit, air popcorn) available for snacking when drinking at a party.
Have low calorie snacks like popcorn, cut up veggies, or rice cakes around when hunger strikes.
Have unflavored milk occasionally to reaquaint your palate with plain milk.
Hide or "unfollow" Facebook updates from friends who upset or annoy you.
Identify exactly when you are skipping meals and plan a quick convenient snack at those times (e.g., Slimfast Shake, breakfast bar)
Identify foods in the home that tempt you and eliminate them from the grocery list.
Identify the foods you munch on when stressed and keep them off your grocery list.
Identify what you are doing when your willpower is weakest and switch to an activity that is incompatible with snacking (e.g., exercising, knitting)
If a persistent host, offer to take leftovers home and then dispose of them.
If a persistent host, tell him/her you are eating light because you don't feel well.
If catering the party, avoid high calorie foods on the menu. Find healthy party recipes.
If drinking for the caffiene, try non-caloric caffienated beverages (tea, coffee)
If having 2 drinks on one occasion, switch to a lower calorie drink for your second drink.
If host insists you eat more than you want, agree instead to take it home for later.
If the host insists you take unwanted leftovers home, take them and throw away on your way home.
If your job has a lot of downtime, bring a book to occupy your mind.
In making your own blended drinks, use extra ice.
Increase fiber content of meals to increase sense of fullness after eating.
Increase protein content of meals to increase sense of fullness after eating.
Increase the duration and/or intensity of your workout earlier in the day to make up for extra calorie later.
Increase your exercise because exercise has been shown to strengthen willpower.
Increase your seafood intake and reduce calories by routinely ordering broiled or grilled seafood when dining out.
Initiate a fun activity away from the food to distract yourself from eating (e.g., active video game, lawn sport, cards)
Keep healthy low calorie snacks at home.
Limit alcohol to one drink at parties
Limit alcohol to one drink at restaurants.
Limit TV to 1 show per evening. Fill the remaining time with a new activity (e.g., exercise, housecleaning, reading)
Limit visits to drive thrus to a certain number per month. Keep track.
Limit yourself to 1 oz. Tell bartender to limit to 1 oz.
Liqueurs are higher in calories, substitute with liquor (e.g., scotch, vodka)
Listen to a book on tape or relaxing music to help calm down during the commute.
Listen to a book on tape or relaxing music to help calm down from work stress during the commute.
Look up menus online and decide what you will order before going.
Look up the calorie amounts of each dessert in a mobile app. Select the one that is most reasonable.
Make a DO NOT BUY list and bring that along with your usual grocery list.
Make a large meal on Sunday so you have leftovers for a couple of days.
Make a list of restaurants that you know have healthy choices and stick to those restaurants.
Make a list of the snacks you overeat when bored and avoid buying those at grocery store.
Make a list of the top 3 restaurants you are mostly likely to overeat at. Limit your visits to these restaurants.
Make a pact to only allow yourself one treat at work a month and keep track in calendar (e.g., bday cake, donut in conference room)
Make a plan to limit time spent with friends who are a source of stress.
Make a reading list and work your way through it.
Make a sign or post a picture in your workspace that reminds you why you want to live a healthy lifestyle.
Make a to do list for home and post on fridge. Work your way through it during times you are bored.
Make a to do list to keep you focused.
Make active social plans with friends (e.g., water aerobics class, visit a park)
Make an appointment with a therapist to learn ways you can cope with stress from family.
Make an appointment with a therapist to learn ways you can cope with stress from friends.
Make appointment with a school counselor for help reducing the stress of your school load
Make at home to control the amount of flavor going in. Gradually reduce the amount in small increments
Make homemade and use non-caloric sweeteners
Make homemade so you can control amount of sugar
Make lower calorie, healthy recipes when catering parties.
Make social plans during times you are bored alone at home.
Make your own wine cooler by mixing wine with club soda or diet tonic. Add fresh fruit for flavor.
Never buy more than 1 bottle at a time.
Never buy more than a 6-pack at a time.
Only prepare the amount of food you will need for the number of guests to avoid leftovers.
Order a healthy appetizer for your meal instead of an entr√©e.
Order a smaller meal when having a higher calorie drink to make up the calories.
Order your drinks after eating your meal, rather than before or during.
Pack a cooler of healthy choices for long trips to eliminate restaurant food and to cut driving time.
Plan a healthy potluck by asking guests to bring their favorite healthy dish (with recipe!)
Plan ahead what you will eat before the event in which you will be drinking.
Plan ahead what you will eat for meals and snacks to avoid impulsive, in the moment unhealthy decisions
Plan an evening exercise routine in the house.
Plan exercise on the weekends if you have these days off of work.
Plan healthy dinners for the week on the weekend to reduce the effort of meal planning each day
Plan in advance what you will order at restaurants on stressful days.
Plan on only going to healthy restaurants on stressful days to reduce opportunity to overeat.
Politely decline the offer to take leftovers home.
Politely decline to eat more when urged.
Practice a deep breathing exercise at least once a day at school to calm down.
Practice a deep breathing exercise at least once a day at work to calm down.
Practice a deep breathing exercise at least once a day to calm down.
Practice tolerating the feeling of hunger for slightly longer periods than you are used to.
Privately mention to the host that you are trying to watch your weight and will need to control your portions.
Put a limit on how many snack foods you can purchase so that you are more selective (e.g., 1 per trip).
Put dumbbells in the office so you can do strength training during down time.
Put dumbbells next to the couch so you can do strength training while watching TV.
Put leftovers in single serving containers and pop in the freezer.
Reduce your restaurant outings to less than 3 per week
Replace with Crystal Light or similar non-caloric drink
Replace with diet soda
Replace with light beer
Replace with seltzer water
Replace with unsweetened tea
Replace with water
Replace with water with fresh lemon or lime
Select light (low-calorie) versions.
Serve all the food you will have all at once on one plate to avoid continous munching.
Set a specific limit on desserts per month and keep track. This will help you decide whether you can have one.
Set a time to talk to partner about ways you need help with childcare/family/home responsibilities.
Sip on herbal tea, coffee, water with fresh lemon or other low calorie beverage.
Slowly reduce the number of sodas you drink per week.
Start a fun activity at parties (e.g., active video game or lawn sport) to keep yourself occupied and away from food.
Subtract one drink from your current usual intake.
Switch to a lower calorie wine (e.g., Skinny Girl).
Switch to an alcoholic beverage that you tend to show better self-control.
Switch your snacks to high protein or high fiber to increase sense of fullness.
Take a hot bath to relax from long day.
Take notes during class to keep your mind focused and off of your tummy.
Take notes to prevent from snacking during class.
Take short walk breaks at school to reduce stress.
Take short walk breaks at work to reduce stress on the job.
Take short walks to break up down time and re-energize your brain.
Take short walks to break up too much time in the house.
Talk to your boss about ways you can reduce the stress of your job.
Tell family members you will only purchase junk food for them if it is a kind you do not like.
Tell host you are watching your weight so he/she doesn't push extra food on you.
Tell the bartender to hold (or go light) the simple syrup or sour mix.
Tell those pressuring you that this is already your third serving (when it is your first)
To give your day structure, make a schedule of your activities of each day in your calendar.
To prevent use of vending machines, don't carry cash.
To reduce calories, substitute starches (e.g., potato, rice, pasta) for steamed or grilled vegetables.
Track your hunger for a few days to help you better space your meals and snacks.
Track your intake with an app or food diary on high stress days to curb overeating.
Use a grocery service like Peapod to avoid all the temptations at the store.
Use a powder mix to control the amount you mix into water. Make a diluted version.
Use a small basket or no basket when you only need a few things so you aren't tempted to add unplanned purchases.
Use an app like Fooducate to identify healthier choices.
Use club soda instead of tonic.
Use diet sodas instead of full-sugar sodas when mixing with soda.
Use non-caloric sweeteners
Use non-dairy creamers
Use only muddled fresh fruit instead of juice or fruit mixes.
Use skim milk instead of whole or 2%
Use small glasses.
Wait 15 minutes to see if hunger passes or intensifies. If it intensifies, have a light snack.
Water drinks down with club soda or water.
When at fast food, use a mobile app like My Fitness Pal to look up calories of menu choices.
When catering a party, be sure to accurately estimate how many servings you will need to avoid a lot of leftovers.
When making large recipes, immediately freeze extras to save for weekday meals.
When one task is getting boring, switch to something new to mix things up.
When ordering food in for parties, make healthy choices (e.g., turkey sub sandwiches, hummus platter, Boston Market)
If sleeping less than 7 hours per night, talk to your doctor about your sleep.
If you don't feel rested even when you sleep 7-8 hours, talk to your doctor about your sleep.
If you skip meals, add the skipped meal back to help control your appetite.
When fatigue strikes, try a short brisk walk before snacking.
Stress may be making you feel exhausted, delegate a few key tasks that will open up some free time for you.
Identify a source of stress that you can eliminate.
Try a deep breathing or other stress reduction exercise when you are feeling fatigued.
Track the time of day you feel fatigued and make sure you only have healthy low calorie options available for snacking.
Make plans to spend time with other moms and their kids/babies during the day
Track the foods you overeat when bored and then ban them from your home.
Find new activities with your kids outside of the house (e.g., library, playground, museum)
Write down a schedule for each day to add structure and reduce downtime for snacking.
Track the time of day you are mostly likely to snack and then make a plan for changing how you spend that time (e.g., exercise at that time, run errands)
